week3.practice3_html:
What it is

Time Your Food helps your digestion and hormones reset overnight by giving your body a few quiet hours between your last meal and sleep. When you stop eating earlier, your body can shift from â€œprocessing modeâ€ to â€œrepair mode,â€ which supports better rest and calmer shedding cycles.

Why this practice matters for you now

Marilou, right now youâ€™re in the stabilization phase â€” the point where your body starts to calm shedding after months of hormonal and stress changes. Because you currently eat about an hour before bed and your sleep runs short and irregular, this practice is your big domino. Creating a twoâ€‘hour buffer before sleep steadies nighttime blood sugar and reduces stress hormones, helping your body step closer to its regrowth window this spring.

Step-by-step implementation

  1. For the next 7 nights, finish your last bite at least two hours before your planned bedtime.
  2. If hunger hits late, choose a calming ritual instead â€” a warm caffeineâ€‘free tea or journaling â€” to remind your brain that rest, not food, is next.
  3. Set a recurring evening reminder on your phone for â€œkitchen closedâ€ time to make the habit automatic.
  4. As your body adjusts, aim for a steady dinner time even on weekends to reinforce your sleep rhythm.

  • Early wins: Falling asleep faster within a week, less bloating or heaviness at bedtime, and waking a bit more refreshed.
  • Watch-outs: Emotional snacking after stressful evenings â€” when that urge shows up, step outside for two deep breaths or wrap your hands around a warm mug of tea instead.
